name: Powdery Mildew
description: Powdery mildew is a common fungal disease that affects a wide variety of plants. It is easily recognized by distinct white, powdery fungal growth on leaves and stems. Unlike many other fungal pathogens, powdery mildew can thrive in dry conditions with high humidity and does not require free water on the leaf surface to germinate.
symptoms: White powdery spots on leaves and stems
Leaves turning yellow and drying out

early_stage.description: Small, circular, white powdery spots appear on leaves (often undersides) and stems.

middle_stage.description: Spots enlarge and merge, covering significant leaf area. Fungal growth becomes denser and may turn gray.

advanced_stage.description: Leaves curl, wither, and brown. Flower buds may fail to open or produce poor quality fruit. Severe infection can stunt plant growth.

causes: Caused by biotrophic fungi in the order Erysiphales. Detailed host specificity depends on the fungal species (e.g., Podosphaera xanthii on cucurbits). Spores (conidia) are spread by wind.

favorable_conditions.humidity: High humidity (wets spores not required), dry foliage
favorable_conditions.environment: Shady areas with poor air circulation and crowded plants

impact.economic_impact: Reduces yield and quality, especially in ornamentals (rosaes) and fruits (grapes, cucurbits)

diagnosis.field_diagnosis: Visual identification of white powdery growth that can be wiped off

prevention: Space plants to ensure good air circulation

cultural_control: Remove and destroy infected plant parts
Water at the base to avoid wetting leaves (though water can sometimes wash off spores, dry foliage is generally preferred to prevent other diseases)

resistant_varieties: Available for many crops like cucumber (e.g., 'Marketmore 76'), melon, and peas.
life_cycle: The fungus overwinters in dormant buds or on plant debris. In spring, spores are released and carried by wind to new growth. The cycle repeats every 7-10 days under favorable conditions.

dataset_metadata.intended_use: Machine learning training, research, and educational purpose
